headline: All not well at Maritime varsity, VC admits
summarized_story:
The Vice-Chancellor declared, “On the issue of N3billion said to have been released by NIMASA, no such money was sent down here.
You see, the way funds are being monitored in the country today, you cannot misappropriate funds again.
So if I’ve diverted such huge funds, by now they would have come after me.
“Permit me, therefore, to set the record straight that at no time was such money released for the settlement of allowances by NIMASA.
“If such money had been released to this institution, I think I would be most excited and I’m sure everybody would have been smiling by now.

headline: US sets global record, announces over one million COVID-19 cases in single day
summarized_story:
The United States recorded more than one million Covid-19 cases on Monday, according to data from Johns Hopkins University, as the Omicron variant spread at a blistering pace.
There were 1,080,211 new cases in the country, a global record, with the number of cases doubling on the previous week.
It comes a day after top US pandemic advisor Anthony Fauci said the country was experiencing “almost a vertical increase” in Covid-19 cases, adding the peak may be only weeks away.
With 9,382 deaths over the past seven days, the nation’s death toll has fallen by 10 percent, week on week.
The US record during previous waves was 258,000 cases per day, for the week of January 5 to 11, 2021.

headline: PDP condoles with Ozigbo over father’s death
summarized_story:
The Peoples Democratic Party has condoled with the governorship candidate of the party in the November 6 Anambra State governorship election, Mr Valentine Ozigbo, over the death of his father.

He said that the entire members and leadership of PDP in Anambra State sympathise with Ozigbo and his family at their moment of grief.

headline: Navy warns public against falling prey to fraudulent recruitment websites
summarized_story:
The Nigerian Navy has alerted the public to be wary of fraudulent websites currently claiming to offer recruitment opportunities for unsuspecting applicants wishing to join the forceIt urged the public to ignore the fake websites and only link up with the authorized and authentic Nigerian Navy website for such exercise.
A statement by Commodore Suleman Dahun, Director of Naval Information, said, “The attention of the Nigerian Navy (NN) has been drawn to the existence of fraudulent websites offering innocent and unsuspecting members of the public recruitment opportunities in the ongoing Nigerian Navy Basic Training School (NNBTS) Batch 33 recruitment exercise.
“Against this background, it has become necessary to advise members of the public to only visit the official recruitment website, https://joinnigeriannavy.com/application-guidelines/ for the purpose of the online registration of the exercise.
“The NN also reiterated that the online registration for the NNBTS Batch Recruitment Exercise has commenced on 3 January and will close on 13 February 2022.”Vanguard News Nigeria

headline: Zamfara bandit kingpin, Bello Turji releases over 70 kidnap victims
summarized_story:
A suspected bandit leader, Bello Turji who has been on the security wanted list, has freed over 70 victims in his custody in Zamfara State.
The development was disclosed by the Co-Chairman of the state Committee on Finding Lasting Solutions to Banditry, Dr. Abdullahi Shinkafi on Tuesday.
Dr. Abdullahi told Channels Television that the victims were freed by the bandit kingpin unconditionally, stressing that the development was a sequel to a military air raid on bandit camps in the state.
According to reports, 70 victims were released following dialogue between the assailants and some local authorities in the state.
It was also gathered that arrangements are being made to evacuate all freed victims to the state capital, Gusau, for profiling and medical treatment before they are released to their families.

headline: Igbo monarchs, bishops to meet Uzodinma, others over Imo crisis
summarized_story:

The Igbo leaders also resolved to intervene and meet with Imo Governor, Senator Hope Uzodinma; the former governorship candidates and elders of the state to find ways to tackle the insecurity and political crisis rocking the state.
Continuing, the Igbo leaders pointed out that the state of affairs in Imo is largely blamed on a few politicians of the state and their cohorts which have constituted an assault on the dignity and well being of the people of Imo and the Igbo nation.
As such we call on all the political gladiators, requesting that they note that the ethos of ndigbo is stepped in ‘egbe belu Ugo ebelu’.
We know what fate is cast on the one that does not allow the other to perch”.

headline: Bandits hide in caves while military bombards women, children, cows – Yobe traditional ruler
summarized_story:
Tukur Mamu, a traditional title holder in Yobe State, has made a fresh revelation about bandits and military bombardments in the state.
Mamu, believed to be in the camp of Sheikh Ahmad Gumi, said bandits told them that they usually run into caves whenever they hear the sound of military aircraft.
The ‘Dan Iyan Fika’ in Yobe State said women, children, and cows are affected by air raids and not bandits.
Speaking with journalists yesterday, the traditional ruler, faulted the approach of security agents in fighting banditry and terrorism.
The traditional ruler charged the military to provide evidence that bandits’ camps were actually bombarded.

headline: Bashir Tofa: We’ve lost key defender of our interests – NEF
summarized_story:
The Northern Elders Forum (NEF) says the demise of June 12, 1993, National Republican Convention presidential election, Alhaji Bashir Othman Tofa, has denied the north an indefatigable defender of the region’s dignity and values.
The forum, in a condolence message issued by its Director of Publicity and Advocacy, Hakeem Baba-Ahmed, noted that the north lost a loyal founding member, a firm believer in responsible and visionary leadership.
According to the statement, “Northern Elders Forum (NEF) and Nigerians are deeply saddened by the death of Alhaji Bashir Othman Tofa.”The statement explained that Nigeria has lost an illustrious son, a consummate politician who was denied the opportunity to provide leadership with the annulment of the Presidential elections In 1992.
The forum, however, condoled with the Supreme Council for Sharia in Nigeria, the people of Kano and Nigerian Muslims over the demise of Dr Datti Ahmad.
It also prayed that Allah (SWA) will reward him for his pioneering service to his community with Aljannah Firdausi.

headline: Lagos blue, red lines rail begins operation Q4, says Sanwo-Olu
summarized_story:
By Lukman OlabiyiLagos State Governor, Babajide Sanwo-Olu, yesterday, said the much-awaited blue and red lines trains are to commence operation before the fourth quarter of the year.
He stated this when he took a tour of the train project from Ikeja, where the red line begins to Yaba, Ebute Meta and finally to Marina where the blue line terminates.
“Our promise on the blue and the red line is still on course.
The red and blue line rail is part of the intermodal transportation system of the Babajide Sanwo-Olu administration in reducing gridlock and ensuring interconnectivity in different parts of the state.

headline: 3 killed in Plateau, Lalong vows to sign death penalty for kidnappers – The Sun Nigeria
summarized_story:

Plateau State Governor, Simon Lalong, in a press statement signed by Director of Press and Public Affairs, Makut Simon Macham, condemned the attack and urged security operatives to unmask the perpetrators.

headline: Electoral bill: Nigeria not ripe for direct primary –IPAC
summarized_story:
From Fred Ezeh, AbujaInter–Party Advisory Council (IPAC) has commended the decision of President Muhammadu Buhari to withhold assent to the amended Electoral Act Bill due to the inclusion of compulsory direct primary for political parties.
IPAC said the president was right in rejecting the bill, stressing that at this stage of democratic journey, Nigeria does not appear to be sufficiently ripe and prepared for the direct primary model in the selection of political party standard bearers.
“The only expressed grouse of the president was the mandatory use of direct primary in the selection of standard bearers of all the political parties.
“This should not be a difficult task given that the two arms are, incidentally, controlled by the same political party, the All Progressives Congress.
Lawmakers should simply expunge the clauses regarding direct primary, thereby, saving the other provisions among which are the one on the mandatory electronic transmission of election results by INEC.

summarized_story:

headline: Breaking: Bashir Tofa, Ex-presidential Candidate, is Dead
summarized_story:
By Ibrahim Shuaibu in KanoAlhaji Bashir Othman Tofa, presidential candidate of the defunct National Republican Convention (NRC) in the June 12, 1993 election, is dead.
Tofa, according to family sources, died at the Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital (AKTH) in the early hours of Monday after a brief illness.
Confirming his death, one of the deceased relations, said: “Alhaji Bashir Tofa died after a brief illness.”Tofa was the challenger of late Chief MKO Abiola, candidate of the defunct Social Democratic Party (SDP), winner of the June 12 election.
The result of the election, which was not fully released officially, was annulled by the military regime of President Ibrahim Babangida.
Born on June 20, 1947 in Kano, the late Tofa was also a businessman, oil trader and industrialist.

summarized_story:
In this video, Senator Ibrahim Shekarau and former Minister of Agriculture, Nanono speak on the death of former Presidential candidate, Alhaji Bashir Tofa.
Mr Tofa, a former presidential candidate of the NRC in the 1993 Presidential Election, died Monday morning at the age of 76.

headline: Buhari, Tinubu, others mourn late Olubadan, Saliu Adetunji
summarized_story:
Tributes are pouring in for the late Olubadan of Ibadan, Oba Saliu Adetunji as President Muhammadu Buhari, Bola Ahmed Tinubu & others have sent their condolence messages.
Oba Adetunji died on Sunday at the University Teaching Hospital, Ibadan.
He was aged 93.

headline: South Africa Parliament: Second Fire Contained, Suspect Due in Court
summarized_story:
A new blaze at the complex housing South Africa’s Parliament in Cape Town has been contained, according to officials, as a suspect arrested in connection with the fire was due to appear in court.
“Around midnight the fire was brought under control,” Cape Town city officials said in a statement on Tuesday.
“To see the walls burning like this, it makes me very sad,” Danny, a Cape Town resident, told Al Jazeera.
A 49-year-old man charged with arson and other offences including theft was expected to appear in court on Tuesday.
The elite Hawks police unit said on Monday the suspect was believed to have gained entry to the Parliament through an office window.

headline: Mali Opposition Rejects Election Delay in New Transition Plan
summarized_story:
A major coalition of political parties in Mali has rejected the military-dominated government’s plan to extend a transition period for up to five years before the country returns to democratic rule.
The transitional government had initially agreed to hold presidential and legislative elections in February 2022, amid pressure from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) regional bloc.
Foreign Minister Abdoulaye Diop submitted the new plans to ECOWAS on Saturday, following a national reform conference boycotted by political parties and social organisations.
The plans envisage a six-month to five-year prolongation of the transition period, starting on January 1 and reversing a pledge to have an 18-month transition government.
Under pressure from former colonial power France and Mali’s neighbours, Goita pledged Mali would return to civilian rule after holding presidential and legislative elections in February this year.

headline: South Africa Parliament Fire Flares Up Again
summarized_story:
A devastating fire which swept through South Africa’s parliament in Cape Town reignited just hours after it was said to be under control.
The fire first broke out on Sunday and completely destroyed the National Assembly, or lower chamber.
The chairperson of the upper chamber, Amos Masondo, said Sunday’s fire had led to the “complete burning down” of the National Assembly chamber.
The Houses of Parliament in Cape Town are made up of three sections, with the oldest dating back to 1884.
Cape Town Mayor Geordin Hill-Lewis said the city’s council chamber would be made available as an alternative place for parliament to meet.

headline: Canadian Families Win $84m Compensation Over Jet Downed by Iran
summarized_story:
A Canadian court has awarded C$107m (£62m; $84m), plus interest, to the families of six people who died when a plane was downed near Tehran in 2020.
The family members awarded compensation by Ontario’s Superior Court of Justice lost spouses, siblings, children, nieces and nephews.
The relatives had filed a civil lawsuit against Iran and other officials who they say were to blame for the incident.
This is the first time that compensation has been awarded to the families of the victims, CBC reports, adding that Iran did not defend itself in court.
Last year a report by the Canadian government said Iran was “fully responsible” for the downing of the plane, and that it had been a result of “incompetence” and “recklessness”.

headline: Former Theranos CEO Holmes Convicted of Fraud and Conspiracy
summarized_story:
A jury convicted Holmes, who was CEO throughout the company’s turbulent 15-year history, on two counts of wire fraud and two counts of conspiracy to commit fraud after seven days of deliberation.
The 37-year-old was acquitted on four other counts of fraud and conspiracy that alleged she deceived patients who paid for Theranos blood tests, too.
Balwani’s trial is scheduled to start next month in the same San Jose courtroom where Holmes’ legal saga unfolded.
Although she was convicted of bamboozling investors, Holmes received a reprieve from the jury on the fraud accusations involving patients who submitted to inaccurate blood tests that could have endangered their health.
Evidence presented at the trial also showed that Holmes lied about purported deals that Theranos had reached with big drug companies such as Pfizer and the U.S. military.
